user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler:
```c
int32 OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler(osal_task_entry function_pointer)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;
    osal_id_t                  task_id;

    task_id     = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        /*
        ** Install the pointer
        */
        task->delete_hook_pointer = function_pointer;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler:
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef osal_task((*osal_task_entry)(void))
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragments in the supplied code that are obviously unreachable under normal compilation/execution. Reasoning by component:

- OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler: control flow is straightforward — it calls OS_TaskGetId_Impl(), then calls OS_ObjectIdGetById() and conditionally executes the block guarded by if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS). Both the true and false branches are reachable at runtime (success and error return paths). The final return return_code; is reachable in all cases. There are no statements placed after an unconditional return or after a branch that always exits the function.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: the early return after OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit on error is valid and reachable when that call fails. The subsequent logic (index conversion, conversion, and possible cancel) is reachable when the init succeeds. There is no dead code sequence (e.g., statements following an unconditional return) inside this function.

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl: the function assigns a value from pthread_getspecific into a union member and returns another union member; this is intentional (commented) and not an unreachable statement. It is executed when the function is called.

- Macros and table accesses (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_task_table, OS_ObjectIdRelease): their usages are conditional on successful token acquisition; they are reachable when OS_ObjectIdGetById returns success.

- Type/typedef declarations shown (osal_id_t, OS_task_internal_record_t, etc.) do not introduce unreachable code by themselves.

Because no code region is syntactically or semantically unreachable (no code after unconditional returns, no constant-false conditional compilation shown, no constructs that always transfer control before some statements), there are no suspicious fragments to investigate for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 in the provided snippets.
